Graphical abstract Developing efficient, cost-effective and robust catalysts for soot combustion is crucial yet challenging. In this study, we fabricated Ag-loaded Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs catalysts (C-type and Cubic fluorite) via different methods, aiming to improve the distribution and interaction of Ag by modifying the crystalline structures of the supports to enhance oxygen activation. The oxygen vacancy concentration and redox performance of the rare earth C-type catalysts exceeded those of the cubic fluorite ones. In the case of the Ag-assisted catalysts, the Sm2Ce2O7–Ag interface with oxygen vacancies displayed an increased affinity for oxygen. The distribution state of Ag on the catalysts is closely related to the Ag–support interactions and the active sites on the support. Experimental analyses and density functional theory (DFT) calculations have revealed a more even dispersion of the Ag species on the C-type catalyst; differential charge density and Bader charge analysis have confirmed that the Ag loadings can alter the surface charge arrangement, resulting in stronger electronic interactions between Ag and the Sm2Ce2O7-C support. Uniformly dispersed Ag species can effectively promote the activation of gaseous O2 molecules, which is key in the oxidation of soot particles. This approach provides a promising strategy for developing more applicable catalysts for soot combustion. Keywords Support phase effect Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs supports DFT insight of Ag-Sm2Ce2O7 interaction Carbon soot oxidation Isotopic 18O2 labelling Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Soot particle emissions from diesel vehicles pose a serious threat to both the environment and human health [1]. With growing public concern for environmental issues, the efficient removal of soot particles has become crucial in environmental pollution control. The diesel particulate filter (DPF), combined with efficient and affordable catalysts, represents a device for eliminating soot particles. Researchers have studied numerous catalysts – including alkali metals [2–4]; rare earth oxides [5,6]; transition metal oxides [7–9]; and composite metal oxides, such as perovskites [10–13], mullites [14], spinels [15–18], and other catalysts – for soot combustion reactions to reduce or replace the use of noble metals and decrease catalyst costs. A2B2O7 compounds are potential catalytic materials for soot oxidation, exhibiting excellent thermal stability and strong oxygen mobility. Wang et al. synthesized a catalyst for soot combustion using K-promoted Pr2Sn2O7 pyrochlore nanospheres. The catalyst’s performance was enhanced by the formation of a macroporous structure and the low melting point of alkali metals, improving the contact between the catalyst and soot [19]. Our group fabricated also Ln2Ce2O7 pyrochlore catalysts for soot combustion and found positive impact of variable valence A-sites on the redox properties as well as reactivities [20]. Further, Feng et al. designed Bi2B2O7 (B = Sn, Ti, Zr) compounds with varying lattice disorder degrees, finding that this parameter is an inherent factor determining the redox properties and reaction performance of the compounds for soot combustion [21]. Previous studies have demonstrated that the performance of A2B2O7 catalysts is closely related to their sub-crystalline phase structure, which is determined by the ratio of the elements A and B (rA/rB) [22]. At the theoretical boundary value of rA/rB, A2B2O7 paramorphs, with identical elemental compositions but exhibiting two crystalline phases, can be fabricated by regulating the temperature, pressure, or other factors [23]. However, research on the catalytic performance of A2B2O7 paramorphs, excluding the effect of differences in the A- and B-site elements, is lacking. We discovered formerly that varying the calcination temperature of La2Zr2O7 can induce a phase transition from the pyrochlore to the disordered defect fluorite structure, leading to a significant difference in the Oxidative Coupling of Methane (OCM) catalytic performance [24]. Research efforts have primarily focused on the structure–activity relationship of the layered perovskite, pyrochlore, and disordered defect fluorite phases, with only a few studies on the rare earth C-type phase. The Ce-based disordered defect fluorite and rare earth C-type phase structures can be easily confused with the solid solution structure. While the crystalline structure of the disordered defect fluorite phase is similar to that of fluorite, the anions and vacancies in the former are disordered, forming defective 8-coordinated polyhedra around the A- and B-site cations (which are also randomly distributed). The A- and B-site cations randomly occupy 4a (0, 0, 0) positions, and oxygen vacancies occur randomly at 8c (¼, ¼, ¼) sites. The rare earth C-type and disordered defect fluorite structures are closely related; the Fm3m symmetry of the fluorite structure decreases to Ia3 symmetry in the former, and the former’s unit cell parameter is doubled compared to the fluorite lattice due to the ordering of vacant anion sites and anion displacement [25]. Over recent years, silver-based catalysts have garnered significant attention due to their high activities and relatively low costs [26–28]. Among various cerium oxide systems loaded with different noble metals, silver species have been identified as very active catalysts. According to Lee et al., Rh/CeO2 and Ag/CeO2 exhibit enhanced soot combustion activity, with superior oxygen vacancy generation, improved oxygen adsorption, and increased electron transfer compared to systems with other noble metals [29]. In another study, Feng et al. employed an XRD extrapolation method to detect the distribution and dispersion of metallic Ag on the SnO2 surface, finding that the nearly amorphous Ag plays a critical role in the reaction [30]. Aiming to develop cost-effective catalysts for soot combustion, we have adopted Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs (fluorite and rare earth C-type) to support Ag to fabricate catalysts. Through the use of various characterization techniques and DFT calculations, we have investigated the distribution state and location of Ag species on the supports. It has been discovered that the crystalline phase structures of the Sm2Ce2O7 supports can significantly influence the Ag-support interactions, which consequently impact the reactivity. With rare earth C-type Sm2Ce2O7 support, a much better Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 catalyst can be fabricated, due to the stronger Ag-support interaction. 2 Methods and materials 2.1 Chemical and materials Sm2O3 (99.9 %), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.99 %), glycine (99.5 %) and AgNO3 (99.9 %) were purchased from Aladdin Technology Co., Ltd. Nitric acid solution (30 %), ethylene glycol (98 %) and ammonia solution (30 %) was purchased from Macklin Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received without additional purification in this study. 99.9 % air, 99.99 % Ar, 10 % H2/Ar, 10 % O2/He, 99.99 % He and 3 % 18O2/He used in this study were purchased from Nanchang Jiangzhu Industry Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst Synthesis 2.2.1 The preparation of Sm2Ce2O7 support The Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst was synthesized using a glycine combustion method. The precursors, 99.9 % Sm2O3 and 99.99 % Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (A.R. grade), were prepared with analytical purity. Firstly, 1.743 g Sm2O3 (5 mmol) was dissolved in nitric acid solution (30 %, 10 mL). Then, 4.342 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (10 mmol) were added and mixed with the Sm2O3 solution. 1.501 g glycine (20 mmol) and 20 mmol ethylene glycol solution were added to the mixture, which was stirred until the solution became clear. The mixture was then transferred to a water bath at 90 °C until it formed a sticky gel. The gel was then transferred to a 300 °C muffle furnace to ignite and collect the powder. Finally, the powder was calcined in a muffle furnace at 600 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1. The sample after grinding uniformly was marked as Sm2Ce2O7-C. The Sm2Ce2O7-F catalyst was synthesized via a co-precipitation method. The precursors with A.R. grade, Sm2O3 and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, were prepared with the same procedure. Afterwards, concentrated aqueous NH3 solution (A.R.) was added dropwise until the pH reached 10. After stirring for 4 h and standing still for 1 h, the yellow precipitate was filtered with a vacuum circulating water pump and washed with deionized water until the TDS of the filtrate was less than 20 ppm. The obtained product was placed in a 110 °C drying oven to dry overnight, and finally calcined in a muffle furnace under an air atmosphere at 600 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1, the sample after grinding was marked as Sm2Ce2O7-F. 2.2.2 The preparation of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 catalysts The Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 catalysts were fabricated using an impregnation method with a 2 % Ag loading. 0.063 g AgNO3 (A.R.) was dissolved in 20 ml double distilled water (DDI) water to obtain a solution. Subsequently, 1.96 g Sm2Ce2O7 was impregnated in a certain amount of this solution for 2 h, and the mixture was evaporated to obtain solid products. The products were then dried at 110 °C for 12 h and finally calcined at 500 °C in air for 4 h with a heating rate of 2°C min−1 to obtain the final catalysts, which were named Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C and Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F catalysts. The Ag content of the catalysts was quantified by ICP and was presented in Table 1 . 2.3 Catalyst characterization The Powder X‐ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Bruker AXS D8 Focus diffractometer instrument with Cu target Kα‐ray irradiation (λ = 0.15405 nm). The data were collected in a range of 10 − 80° with a step of 2° min−1. The lattice parameters were determined by XRD Rietveld refinement method. Raman spectra were measured using a Renishaw in Via instrument with an Ar laser of 532 nm, and the Raman shift ranges from 200 to 1300 cm−1. N2 sorption experiments were performed on an ASAP-2020 instrument at 77 K. The Brunauer‐Emmett‐Teller (BET) method was used to calculated the specific surface areas at relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.05‐0.25. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was used to calculate the pore size distribution and the average pore sizes. The average pore volumes were accumulated at P/P0 = 0.99. Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDX), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were recorded using a TecnaiTM F30 transmission electron microscope. O2–H2 titration experiments were performed using the BelCata II chemisorption instrument equipped with a Belmass mass spectrometer. The experiment began by treating a 100 mg sample under a 99.99 % He flow for 30 min. The sample was then reduced in a 10 % H2/Ar flow and heated from 30 °C to 400 °C for 2 h (at a rate of 10 °C/min). Next, the sample was cooled down to 170 °C under a 10 % H2/Ar flow and purged with a 99.99 % He flow for 1 h to remove any remaining hydrogen gas. A 10 % O2/Ar mixture flow was pulsed onto the sample to saturate the surface, pulsed by 10 % H2/Ar flow. This process was repeated multiple times through a quantitative tube to titrate the chemisorbed O2 until the peak area is constant. Based on the new Ag dispersion data (D) in Table 1, the Ag crystallite size (d) was estimated with the equation of d (nm) = 1.34/D, by assuming a spherical Ag model [31]. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2‐TPR) experiments were taken on FINESORB 3010C instrument. The catalysts (50 mg) were pretreated in a 99.9 % air flow at 120 °C for 30 min, and then flushed with an 99.99 % Ar flow at 30°C for 30 min. It was then heated from 30°C to 700 °C (10 °C min−1, in a 30 mL min−1 10 % H2/Ar gas flow). A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to monitor H2 uptake, and a 99.99 % CuO sample was used as the calibration standard to quantify the H2 consumption amount. Oxygen temperature programmed desorption (O2‐TPD) experiments were conducted using a Micromeritics Auto Chem 2920 chemical adsorption instrument equipped with a TCD. 50 mg sample was pretreated in a 30 mL min−1 99.99 % Ar flow at 400 °C for 60 min and then cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, the sample was saturated in a 10 % O2/He flow for 1 h with a rate of 30 mL min−1, followed by purging with a 30 mL min−1 99.99 % He flow for 20 min. The experiments were then carried out from 50 to 800 °C (10 °C min−1, in a 30 mL min−1, 99.99 % He flow), while O2 was measured by a TCD detector. Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) experiments were performed on a JEOL FA-200 EPR spectrometer. After pretreated in an oxygen atmosphere (at 350 °C and 100 Torr for 1 h), the catalyst was cooled to room temperature, and then introduced to a 10 % O2/Ar gas mixture flow to saturate the surface. The catalyst was captured at liquid nitrogen temperature of 77 K and the signal was collected at room temperature. In situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transformations Spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTS) experiments were tested on a Bruker FTIR spectrometer equipped with an in situ diffuse reflectance pool and an MCT detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. The active surface oxygen species on the catalyst was investigated in the desired gas atmosphere in a range of 600–4000 cm−1 at 350 °C with 32 scans. The catalyst was pretreated to remove surface pollutants (at 500 °C, in a 30 mL∙min−1 99.99 % Ar flow for 1 h), then collected baseline at 30°C and raised to 350°C. A 10 % O2/Ar flow was introduced into the in-situ cell at 350 °C for 15 min. The 10 % H2/Ar flow and 10 % O2/Ar flow were introduced step by step. X‐ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) tests were carried out on a PerkinElmer PHI1600 instrument with a Mg Kα X-ray source, which was operated at 300 W and 15 kV. The binding energy was calibrated using the C 1 s peak of standard graphite at 284.8 eV. Pulsed isotopic 18O2 exchange experiments were tested on the BelCata II chemisorption instrument equipped with a Belmass mass spectrometer. The sample (250 mg) was pretreated in a 30 mL min−1 99.99 % He flow at 500 °C and then cooled to 50 °C. The sample was heated to 450 °C and stabilize the baseline, a 3 % 18O2/He flow was pulsed onto it with a 1 mL loop for each pulse. The relevant m/z fragments were monitored to trace the signal change of 16O2 (m/z = 32), 16O18O (m/z = 34) and 18O2 (m/z = 36). Isothermal 18O2 temperature programmed surface reaction − Mass spectrometry (TPSR-MS) experiments were carried out on MicroActive for AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a Belmass mass spectrometer. The mixture of 50 mg catalyst and 5 mg soot particles was treated at 120°C under a 99.99 % He flow for 1 h to remove any possible impurities, and then decreased to 30°C. Subsequently, the temperature was programmed to 500 °C by introducing a 3 % 18O2/Ar flow, and the exhaust gas was connected to a mass spectrometer to record the signals of C16O2 (m/z = 44), C16O18O (m/z = 46), and C18O2 (m/z = 48). Isothermal experiments were also conducted on MicroActive for AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a Belmass mass spectrometer. The catalyst and soot particle mixtures were treated at 120 °C under a 99.99 % He flow for 1 h; thereafter, the temperature was raised to 400 °C and maintained, then a 3 % 18O2/Ar gas mixture was introduced, and a mass spectrometer to record the signals of C16O2 (m/z = 44), C16O18O (m/z = 46), and C18O2 (m/z = 48). 2.4 Activity Evaluation Temperature programmed oxidation-Mass spectrometry (TPO-MS) technique was used to evaluate the soot combustion activity performance of the catalysts using a FINESORB-3010C multiple adsorption instrument (Finetec, China) and a QMS-1800 mass spectrometer (Finetec, China) [21]. Typically, 50 mg catalyst powder was mixed with 5 mg soot (Printex-U, diameter of 25 nm, purchased from Degussa) and grounded for 10 min in a tight contact mode, and then the mixture was diluted by 100 mg inert silica. The data were measured from 120°C to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 (in a 10 % O2/Ar flow, 30 ml min−1). The signal m/z = 44 and 28 was used to detect the generation of CO2 in the exhaust gas, and m/z = 28 and 16 was used to detect CO. For a TPO reaction, the conversion of soot particles (Xsoot) and the CO2 selectivity (SCO2) at a certain temperature can be calculated by the formula (1) and (2) in sequence: (1) X soot = A T - C O + A T - C O 2 A Max - C O + A Max - C O 2 ∗ 100 % (2) S C O 2 = A Max - C O 2 A Max - C O 2 + A Max - C O ∗ 100 % f, an average splitting ratio (f = A28/A44) was used to calculate the contribution of the m/z = 28 fragments from CO2; ACO, the accurate relative amount of CO product, which can be defined as AT-CO = A28 − A44 × f; ACO2, the accurate relative amount of CO2 product can be defined as AT-CO2 = A44 × (1 + f); the totally released amount of CO2 (AMax-CO2) and CO (AMax-CO) can be defined. Isothermal reaction was studied with the mixture of 20 mg catalyst and 2 mg soot particles at 350 °C, at which the soot conversion can be controlled < 20 % on the samples, thus being able to achieve data in a kinetic regime. The tests were conducted in a quartz reactor with a 10 % O2/Ar flow (100 mL min−1). In this way, the reaction rates (Rw) over all the catalysts for soot combustion can be calculated from this equation. R w = n c o 2 × A 0 A t × m cat × t Rw (mol∙g−1∙s−1) is calculated from normalizing the soot conversion amount by catalyst mass (mcat) and reaction time (t). The soot conversion amount is quantified through the CO2 formation amount in this process (A0) by the total CO2 formation amount (At) supposing that all the soot particle are combusted. For the isothermal anaerobic titrations, soot is used as the probing molecules. After the reaction is stabilized at 350 °C in a 10 % O2/Ar flow, the feed is instantaneously switched to a 99.9 % He flow. The CO2 concentration decrease from the steady state was monitored by a gas analyzer until it dropped to zero concentration. The number of soot reactive oxygen sites (O*) is quantified through dividing the CO2 formation amount in this process (A0) by the total CO2 amount (At) supposing all the 2 mg soot particle are combusted, thus getting a coefficient (k = A0/At). Based on this, the soot reactive oxygen site number (O*) can thus be calculated with the equation here: O* = k*msoot/Msoot*NA. In the equation, msoot represents the soot particle mass, Msoot is the molecule weight of carbon, and NA is Avogadro constant. The turnover frequency (TOF) reflects the intrinsic activity, which was calculated through dividing the reaction rates (Rw) by the numbers of soot reactive oxygen sites (O*), as expressed here with the equation of TOF = Rw/O*. 2.5 DFT calculations All calculations in this study were conducted using density functional theory (DFT) with the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP). The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was employed for the exchange–correlation energy. Electron-ion interactions were modeled using the Projector Augmented Wave (PAW) method. To minimize interactions between periodic images in slab model calculations, a 15 Å vacuum spacing was introduced. Ag4 cluster was manually added to the Sm2Ce2O7-F (111) and Sm2Ce2O7-C (222) slab model. Based on convergence tests of total energy, the cutoff energy was set at 450 eV for all structures. Convergence criteria were established for the self-consistent field (1.0 × 10−6 eV/atom), energy (1.0 × 10−5 eV/atom), force (0.03 eV/Å), atomic displacement (1.0 × 10−3 Å), and stress components (0.05 GPa). Adsorption energy calculations followed the formula: Eads = Etot − Eslab − Emol, where Eads is the adsorption energy, Etot is the total energy of the adsorbed structure, Eslab is the energy of the surface, and Emol is the energy of the adsorbed molecule. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Bulk and surface properties As illustrated in Fig. 1 (a), two Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs were successfully synthesized, as evidenced by the XRD patterns matching the characteristic peaks of the standard cards (Sm2Ce2O7-F: PDF#97–029-1270, and Sm2Ce2O7-C: PDF#97–018-7614) [23]. This is further confirmed by the XRD Rietveld refinement results presented in Fig. S1 and Table 1. The Raman spectra of the two Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs, as shown in Fig. 1 (b), are highly similar, with the characteristic peaks at 470 and 580 cm−1 attributed to the disordered defect fluorite phase [32]. Notably, the Raman band located at 370 cm−1 in the Sm2Ce2O7-C spectrum is a characteristic peak of the rare earth C-type phase, distinct from the fluorite phase [22]. The surface atomic ratios are given in Table 1, with the Sm/Ce ratios slightly higher than 1:1. The structures of the two catalysts are closely related, with the rare earth C-type structure referred to as a superstructure of fluorite due to its structural distortion [25]. A sketch of the Sm2Ce2O7 paramorph structures is presented in Fig. 1 (e). The full unit cells of the fluorite and rare earth C-type phases were compared; the lattice parameters from the XRD Rietveld refinement demonstrate that Sm2Ce2O7-F and Sm2Ce2O7-C belong to the Fm3m and Ia3 space groups, respectively. The unit cell parameter of the C-type phase (10.923 Å) is twice that of the F-type one (5.457 Å) [20,25]. In Sm2Ce2O7-F, the A3+ and B4+ cations randomly occupy 4a (0, 0, 0) sites, and the 1/8 oxygen vacancies randomly occupy 8c (¼, ¼, ¼) sites [22]. In Sm2Ce2O7-C, one A-cation coordinate and the four atomic coordinates of the O site move out from the special position. The 4a (0, 0, 0) and 8c (¼, ¼, ¼) positions are separated into two Wyckoff sites, with cations at the 8b and 24d sites and oxide ions occupying the 48e and 16c sites. The cation at the 24d site could move away from the center and influence the distribution of interatomic distances for the M−M pairs, according to the oxygen vacancy (VO) ordering and the electrostatic repulsion with VOs. The M−M distances in the C-type phase are separated into two distinct sets, and the M−O pairs are disordered [25]. After loading the samples with silver, peaks at 2θ = 38.2°, 44.3°, and 64.5° were observed in the XRD patterns of the Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs; these can be attributed to metallic silver, with no AgOx species detected [33,34]. The Ag crystallite sizes were obtained from the XRD patterns and listed in Table 1, which are 3.1 and 3.7 nm for Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C and Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F, respectively. Therefore, the Raman spectra of the loaded samples do not exhibit obvious changes. As shown in Fig. 1 (c), the relative oxygen vacancy contents – evaluated from the I580/I470 ratios in the Raman spectra – decrease in the following order: Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C > Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F > Sm2Ce2O7-C > Sm2Ce2O7-F [20]. The number of oxygen vacancies on the surface of Sm2Ce2O7-C is significantly higher than that for Sm2Ce2O7-F, with the silver loadings enhancing the oxygen vacancy content on the surface of the catalysts. This is consistent with previous studies, which suggest that the presence of Ag particles on the surface of CeO2 leads to a larger defect concentration, causing the CeO2 lattice to contract or expand [35]. As shown in Fig. 1 (d), the presence of metallic Ag is confirmed by the Ag 3d5/2 binding energy of ∼ 367.6 eV and Ag 3d3/2 binding energy of ∼ 373.6 eV for both catalysts, which is also supported by the XRD analysis [36–38]. Additionally, the binding energies of 368.0 and 374.0 eV are attributed to the presence of Ag2O, which was not detected by XRD [35,39]. Moreover, the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst exhibit a higher relative ratio of Ag+ species to the total species (61.78 %) compared to the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F catalyst (52.02 %), indicating that the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst has more abundant surface-active oxygen species, which can keep Ag at more oxidized state. The active oxygen species are originated mainly from the chemisorption of O2 on the surface vacancies [40]. Indeed, this might imply the presence of a stronger interactions between Ag and the Sm2Ce2O7-C support. This also indicates the formation of small quantities of amorphous Ag2O species on the surface of the Ag nanoparticles. As depicted in Fig. S2 , the Sm2Ce2O7-F catalyst involves stacked nanoparticles, while the Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst possesses a porous structure. The morphologies of the catalysts do not change after loading with Ag. The catalysts exhibit type IV isotherms and H3 hysteresis loops, with specific surface areas ranging from 12–19 m2∙g−1, as displayed in Fig. S3 , Tables 1 and Tables S1. Notably, the pore sizes of Sm2Ce2O7-C and Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C are evenly distributed in the range of 5–40 nm, conducive to efficient contact with soot particles. As shown in Fig. 2 (a, b), the (111) and (220) facets of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F are identified with a d-spacing of 0.309 and 0.190 nm. The typical (222) and (440) facets of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C are identified with d-spacings of 0.314 and 0.193 nm, respectively [23,41]. Moreover, metallic Ag particles (<10 nm) can be observed by a lattice fringe of 0.236 nm, which corresponds to the Ag (111) facets, and no AgOx species were detected [35]. Considering the mapping results in Fig. 2 (c, d), the metallic Ag particles are well-dispersed on the Sm2Ce2O7-C support, while partially aggregated and larger Ag particles are visible on the Sm2Ce2O7-F catalyst. Ag dispersion on the catalysts was detected by O2–H2 titration experiments, as shown in Table 1 and Fig. S4 ; Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C exhibits greater dispersion than Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F, indicating the fine dispersion of Ag on Sm2Ce2O7-C [31]. The calculated sizes of Ag nanoparticles on Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C and Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F are 3.2 and 3.7 nm in sequence, which are consistent with the XRD results. 3.2 Catalytic performance for soot combustion Fig. 3 (a, b) illustrates the soot combustion activity of the catalysts, determined using temperature programmed oxidation-mass spectrometry (TPO-MS). For comparison, the T50 value for pure soot oxidation is 600 °C [42]. The Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs display different catalytic activities, with the T50 of the Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst at 465 °C, 44 °C lower than that of Sm2Ce2O7-F (T50 = 509°C). After loading with Ag, the activity of the catalysts improves significantly. The T50 of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F decreases to 406 °C, which is 103 °C lower than that of the Sm2Ce2O7-F support. Notably, Sm2Ce2O7-C possesses much more abundant surface defects than Sm2Ce2O7-F, hence showing higher soot combustion activity than on Sm2Ce2O7-F. When being subjected to the same optimization condition, Sm2Ce2O7-F with lower original activity could have more obvious compensation effects than Sm2Ce2O7-C. Indeed, this could be the reason that loading Ag onto Sm2Ce2O7-F (ΔT50 = 103°C) have more evident enhancement effect than loading Ag onto Sm2Ce2O7-C (ΔT50 = 89°C). Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C shows the optimal soot combustion catalytic performance, with T10, T50, and T90 values of 334, 376, and 398°C, respectively. The catalytic activities follow the sequence Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C > Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F > Sm2Ce2O7-C > Sm2Ce2O7-F. Compared with Ag/CeO2 (T50 = 403°C) prepared using the same method ( Fig. S5 ), Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C demonstrates much better activity. Furthermore, Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C exhibits also better performance than most of the reported catalysts ( Table S2 ). The CO2 selectivity of all the catalysts is close to 100 % to avoid secondary contamination from the generation of CO. Isothermal anaerobic titration experiments at 350 °C were conducted to elucidate the intrinsic activity of the catalysts further [43]. As presented in Table 2 , the turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated as the ratio of the reaction rate (Rw) in Fig. 3 (c) to the soot active oxygen amount (O*) in Fig. S6 . The Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst exhibits the highest reaction rate (0.82 μmol∙g−1∙s−1) in the soot combustion process. Moreover, it possesses the highest active oxygen amount among the catalysts, eightfold greater than the value for Sm2Ce2O7-F. Furthermore, the TOF value of the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst is the largest (1.50 × 10−3 s−1), indicating that the optimal catalyst could enhance the intrinsic catalytic activity for soot combustion. The TOF of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst in this study falls within a favorable range when compared to the values reported in the literatures ( Table S3 ). The Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst displays a mild deactivation during the five consecutive TPO experiments, as shown in Fig. 3 (d). As shown in Fig. S7 , the XRD and Raman results indicate that the phase structure of the used catalyst remains unchanged. However, its specific surface area decreased from 12.5 to 10.2 m2∙g−1, which could be the main cause for the mild activity deactivation. It exhibits notable catalytic performance and reaction stability for soot combustion, rendering it a promising candidate for the removal of soot particles in real engine applications. 3.3 Characterization of redox properties and surface oxygen species The redox properties of the Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs were investigated via H2-TPR tests, as presented in Fig. S8 (a). According to previous studies, the reduction peaks at 450 and 790 °C for pure CeO2 are attributed to the reduction of surface Ce4+ and surface lattice oxygen, respectively [44]. The H2-TPR profile of Sm2Ce2O7-C exhibits reduction peaks at 370 and 511 °C, corresponding to the reduction of active surface oxygen species in different chemical environments [45]. On the other hand, Sm2Ce2O7-F has a reduction peak at 489 °C, associated with the reduction of surface oxygen species. The amount of reducible oxygen species on Sm2Ce2O7-C is higher than that on Sm2Ce2O7-F, which may be attributed to the weaker Ce-O bond strength of the former catalyst compared to the latter. Based on the XRD, XPS, and HRTEM results, the Ag species on the Sm2Ce2O7 supports are mainly present in the form of metallic Ag, with a small quantity of AgOx species. The reduction temperature of the supported catalysts is lower, arising from the hydrogen overflow caused by the stronger interaction of Ag and Sm2Ce2O7 [46,47]. During this process, H2 can be adsorbed onto the metallic Ag and dissociate to produce hydrogen atoms, which could easily migrate to the surface of the Sm2Ce2O7 catalysts to promote the reduction [48,49]. Fig. S8 (b) shows the O2-TPD profiles of the catalysts, which exhibit three types of oxygen species with different desorption temperature ranges. The peaks below 150 °C, those from 150–500 °C, and those from 500–800 °C can be ascribed to the desorption of chemisorbed oxygen species, but with weaker bonding to the surface, active surface oxygen species (O2 − and O2 2−), and lattice oxygen (O2−), respectively [50]. The quantified results in Table 3 indicate that the oxygen desorption amount of the catalysts decreases in the order Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C > Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F > Sm2Ce2O7-C > Sm2Ce2O7-F, corresponding to the soot combustion catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), EPR spectra were used to detect oxygen vacancy/defect (g = 2.003); and the amount of oxygen vacancy/defect is consistent with the Raman results [51,52]. The optimal catalyst, Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C, was selected for in situ DRIFTS experiments to identify the active surface oxygen species, as presented in Fig. 4 (b). After the pretreatment process, the catalyst was tested at 350 °C for 15 min. After pumping a 10 % O2/Ar gas flow into the in situ diffuse reflectance pool, the IR bands at 870 and 1114 cm−1 were identified as surface peroxide (O2 2−) and superoxide (O2 −), respectively [20]. 3.4 XPS and DFT analyses of Ag–Sm2Ce2O7 interactions Fig. 5 (a) depicts the O 1 s signals of the catalysts, which were deconvoluted based on the EPR, in situ DRIFTS, and XPS C 1 s results (as shown in Fig. S9 ). The asymmetric O 1 s spectra can be divided into four peaks, located at around 533.3, 531.6, 530.0, and 528.9 eV and corresponding to the O2 −, CO3 2−, O2 2−, and O2− species, respectively. Furthermore, the (O2 2− + O2 −)/O2− ratios are presented in Table S4 . The ratio of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C is higher than that of the other catalysts, indicating a high surface oxygen vacancy concentration and abundant active surface species on the catalyst, which could enhance the soot combustion activity. The Ce 3d spectra in Fig. 5 (b) are labeled as “u” and “v”, referring to the 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 spin–orbit components, respectively. The four peaks labeled as v0, v’, u0, and u’ correspond to the Ce3+ cations, and the remaining peaks are characteristic of Ce4+ [39,53]. As presented in Table S4 , the Ce3+ percentages of the catalysts follow the order Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C > Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F > Sm2Ce2O7-C > Sm2Ce2O7-F, indicating that the loading of Ag induces the formation of Ce3+. The generation of oxygen vacancies is closely related to the Ce3+ content, which follows the same sequence as that for the oxygen vacancy concentration of the catalysts. These results imply that during the soot combustion reaction, the Ag loadings create additional oxygen vacancies, thus generating more active surface oxygen species to react with soot particles [49]. Fig. 5 (a) and Fig. S10 display the electron transfer behavior of elements on the Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs, as determined via XPS analyses and DFT calculations. A slight increase of 0.5 ∼ 0.6 eV of Sm 3d arises after loading Ag, while the O 1 s spectra of the Ag-loaded catalysts exhibit a decrease of 0.2 ∼ 0.3 eV compared to the unsupported catalysts, indicating an increased electron density around the metal center. After examining the Ce 3d XPS spectra for potential charge transfer effects, we noted that Ag acts as an electron donor to Sm2Ce2O7, resulting in the formation of an Ag+ cation and a reduced Ce3+ ion. Differential charge density and Bader charge analysis confirmed a difference in the anchoring strength of Ag on the Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs [54,55]. As depicted in Fig. 5 (c, d), the positive and negative charge transfer on the C-type catalyst is more pronounced than that on the F-type one. As revealed by the Bader charge analysis in Fig. 5 (c, d), Ag acts as an electron donor, transferring electrons to the support along the oxygen bridge; the number of electrons transferred from Ag to Sm2Ce2O7-C (1.29 e−) is greater than that from Ag to Sm2Ce2O7-F (0.21 e−) [56,57]. Meanwhile, Sm and Ce also provide electrons, and electron enrichment occurs on the lattice oxygens, which is beneficial for oxygen activation (verified by the XPS results). This result corresponds to the differences in the electronegativities of the elements in Table S5 . The electron work function supports the conclusion that electrons flow from the interfacial Ag atoms (Φ Ag = 4.5–4.7 eV) to CeO2 (Φ CeO2 = 4.5–6.3 eV) until the Fermi levels of Ag and CeO2 become aligned and a Helmholtz double layer is established [53,58]. The crystal structure of the support modulates the Ag dispersion state and interactions between Ag and Sm2Ce2O7. The Ag loadings on the Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs alter the surface charge arrangement, undergo rearrangement, and exhibit strong electronic interactions, with the strongest electronic interaction occurring between Ag and the Sm2Ce2O7-C support. 3.5 18O2 isotopic exchange labelling and the oxygen adsorption energy Fig. 6 (a) illustrates the DFT calculation results of the oxygen adsorption energies of thermodynamically stable configurations of the Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs [59]. The oxygen adsorption energy of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C (−2.60 eV) is lower than that of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F (−1.55 eV), indicating a stronger ability to adsorb and activate gaseous oxygen for soot combustion. Fig. 6 (b) presents the pulsed isotopic 18O2 exchange results on the catalysts. Prior to the experiment, the catalysts were pretreated in a 99.99 % He flow at 500 °C and subsequently cooled to 50 °C to clean the surfaces. After heating to 450 °C and getting a stable baseline. A 3 % 18O2/He flow was pulsed onto the catalysts with a 1 mL loop, and the 16O2 (m/z = 32), 16O18O (m/z = 34) and 18O2 (m/z = 36) signals were recorded for each pulse. The sum of the three oxygen signals (18O2, 16O18O, and 16O2) at 450 °C is used as the standard for comparison, and the percentages of the 16O18O and 16O2 species are particularly compared in Fig. 6 (c). The main signals detected on the Sm2Ce2O7-F and Sm2Ce2O7-C catalysts are 18O2, and the consumed 18O2 amount on Sm2Ce2O7-C is greater than that on Sm2Ce2O7-F. On each Sm2Ce2O7 catalyst, the magnitudes of the 16O2 and 16O18O signals are similar, indicating a limited surface oxygen overflow capability. Nevertheless, after loading Ag, each Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 catalyst displays evidently more intensive 16O2 signals than 16O18O signals. Furthermore, the oxygen exchange capacity of Sm2Ce2O7-C is greater than that of Sm2Ce2O7-F, as demonstrated by its higher 16O2 percentage. Notably, the abundance of 16O2 signal is closely related to the amount of surface and bulk vacancies/defects of a catalyst. On a catalyst with rich defects, the pulsed 18O2 will exchange rapidly with two surface 16O2− anions to form a 16O2 molecules, with two 18O2− anions being formed and staying on the surface lattice sites. Usually, this process is more favored on a catalyst with rich defects, which usually has adjacent vacancies, or the bulk vacancy can migrate to the surface quickly. In other words, the amount of 16O2 can reflect the abundance of surface and bulk vacancies/defects of a catalyst [60]. This indicates that Sm2Ce2O7-C has a stronger ability to exchange oxygen at this temperature, consistent with the calculated oxygen adsorption energies in Fig. 6 (a). Considering the oxygen exchange signals (16O2 and 16O18O) of both the Sm2Ce2O7-F and Sm2Ce2O7-C catalysts, the main R2 mechanism is performed by the Ag-loaded Sm2Ce2O7, and the oxygen overflow capability is elevated with the introduction of Ag [22]. 3.6 Isothermal oxidation of soot over the catalysts Based on the results of activity tests and isotopic 18O2 exchange experiments, both the Sm2Ce2O7 catalysts possess defects, which can generate active surface oxygen species under an oxygen-rich atmosphere but with different amount. Furthermore, the adsorption and activation of gaseous oxygen are enhanced upon loading Ag, leading to improved catalytic activity. To investigate the role of different oxygen species on the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 played in soot oxidation, the mixture of 50 mg catalyst and 5 mg soot particles was pretreated in a 99.99 % He flow at 120 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the temperature was programmed to 500 °C in a 3 % 18O2/Ar flow. The effluent gas was monitored by a mass spectrometer to record C16O2 (m/z = 44), C16O18O (m/z = 46), and C18O2 (m/z = 48) signals. For both the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F and Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C catalysts, the signals of C16O2, C16O18O, and C18O2 appear sequentially but with some difference. Fig. 7 (a) shows the normalized percentages of the isotopic CO2 to the total area of the three signals. The firstly appeared C16O2 signal is due to the reaction between soot particle and the originally formed active surface oxygen species. The embedded ratio of C16O2 on Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C (43 %) is higher than that on Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F (40 %). Moreover, the C16O2 signal appears at 150 °C on Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F, while on Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C, it appears at a lower temperature of 100 °C. This is due to the higher concentration of surface-active oxygen species on the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst, resulting in the oxidation of more soot particles at lower temperatures. On the other hand, the signals for C16O18O and C18O2 on Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C begin to appear at 200 and 300 °C, respectively, with an onset temperature lower than that of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F, indicating that soot can be oxidized on Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C at lower temperatures. The appearance of isotopic CO2 species testifies that at elevated temperature, gaseous 18O2 can be exchanged and activated on Ag or surface defects, and Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C has obviously a stronger ability to accomplish this than Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-F. Fig. 7 (b) presents the results of isothermal experiments to observe the products of soot combustion on the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 catalysts. As above, the mixture of a catalyst and soot particle was treated at 120 °C under a 99.99 % He flow for 1 h. After this, differed procedure was adopted here. In specific, the temperature was raised to 400 °C and maintained, then a 3 % 18O2/Ar gas flow was introduced for an isothermal reaction with time on stream. As displayed in Fig. 7 (b), after introducing the 18O2/Ar gas, the main product of C16O2 is first generated as above; and gives rise to a sharp signal reaching its maximum value in approximately 190 s, and then gradually decreases. The signals of C16O18O and C18O2 gradually increase, and reach their maximum values, and then gradually decrease, with the C16O18O signal being larger than that of C18O2. The embedded quantitative results indicate that Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C can also consume more soot particles in the isothermal reactions. The possible reaction pathways based on the different products for soot oxidation on Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 (c). Initially, a large amount of originally formed active 16O species on the catalyst surfaces react to soot particles to form C16O2 product. With time extension at 400°C, gas phase 18O2 starts to be exchanged and activated on the surface to form active oxygen species and react with soot, resulting in the appearance of C16O18O and C18O2 signals. From 500–600 s, after the depletion of active 16O surface species, C18O2 becomes the main product. This indicates that the gaseous 18O2 molecules can fully adsorb and dissociate on the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 catalysts with time extension, which then react with the contacted soot particles [61,62]. In summary, Ag loaded on Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs with different sub-crystalline phases exhibit distinct difference in reactivity. Although the constituent elements are the same, Sm2Ce2O7-C owns much more bulk and surface defects than Sm2Ce2O7-F, thus demonstrating stronger redox performance. The distribution state of Ag is closely related to the richness of surface defective sites on the catalyst. On Sm2Ce2O7-C support with richer amounts of defects, Ag exhibits a more uniform distribution than on Sm2Ce2O7-F, hence leading to a stronger Ag-support interaction. As a consequence, a larger quantity of active oxygen species (O2 − and O2 2−) can be produced over Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C. The isotopic 18O2 soot oxidation ( Fig. 7 ) and the activity test results have proven that these active oxygen species are the key factors to promote the soot oxidation activity [63]. Based on these results, it is concluded that the crystalline phase of Sm2Ce2O7 can significantly impact the activity of the supported Ag catalyst. 4 Conclusions In this study, Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs with two sub-crystalline structures, namely, rare earth C-type and disordered defect fluorite, were synthesized and used as supports to fabricate Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 catalysts. The activity of both catalyst types was notably enhanced following the loading of Ag. The Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C catalyst exhibited superior activity in soot combustion (T50 = 376°C, TOF = 1.50 × 10−3 s−1). Mapping and H2 pulse experiments revealed the formation of more, well-dispersed Ag0 species on the Ag/Sm2Ce2O7-C. The H2-TPR and O2-TPD techniques revealed this catalyst has looser structure and greater redox properties. The C-type structure exhibited a superior oxygen exchange capacity and abundant active surface oxygen species, contributing to its enhanced catalytic activity in soot particle combustion, as determined by the EPR, in situ DRIFTS, and isotopic oxygen exchange reaction results. Based on experimental analyses and DFT calculations, the electronic interaction and transfer between Ag and the Sm2Ce2O7-C is much stronger than that between Ag and Sm2Ce2O7-F, which is beneficial for oxygen activation. Furthermore, the enhanced interaction between well-dispersed Ag nanoparticles and Sm2Ce2O7-C supports promotes the dissociation and activation of gaseous oxygen, thereby significantly improving its catalytic soot oxidation performance. In brief, an apparent support phase structure effect is present, which is the intrinsic reason to improve the reactivity of Ag/Sm2Ce2O7 catalysts. The results reported in this work might provide insights for the design of active Ag-based and cost-effective catalysts for soot oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Developing efficient, cost-effective and robust catalysts for soot combustion is crucial yet challenging. In this study, we fabricated Ag-loaded Sm2Ce2O7 paramorphs catalysts (C-type and Cubic fluorite) via different methods, aiming to improve the distribution and interaction of Ag by modifying the crystalline structures of the supports to enhance oxygen activation. The oxygen vacancy concentration and redox performance of the rare earth C-type catalysts exceeded those of the cubic fluorite ones. In the case of the Ag-assisted catalysts, the Sm2Ce2O7–Ag interface with oxygen vacancies displayed an increased affinity for oxygen. The distribution state of Ag on the catalysts is closely related to the Ag–support interactions and the active sites on the support. Experimental analyses and density functional theory (DFT) calculations have revealed a more even dispersion of the Ag species on the C-type catalyst; differential charge density and Bader charge analysis have confirmed that the Ag loadings can alter the surface charge arrangement, resulting in stronger electronic interactions between Ag and the Sm2Ce2O7-C support. Uniformly dispersed Ag species can effectively promote the activation of gaseous O2 molecules, which is key in the oxidation of soot particles. This approach provides a promising strategy for developing more applicable catalysts for soot combustion.
